quoteLast: , we pushed forward through the sun, which presently was mitigated by heavy nimbi, to Liberty Farm, where a station supplied us with the eternal eggs and bacon of these _mangeurs de lard_. It is a dish constant in the great West, as the omelet and pigeon in the vetturini days of Italy, when, prompted by the instincts of self-preservation, the inmates of the dove-cot, unless prevented in time, are said to have fled their homes at the sight of Milordo’s traveling carriage, not to return until the portent had disappeared.
title: The City of the Saints, and Across the Rocky Mountains to California
author: Burton, Richard Francis, Sir, 1821-1890

quoteLast: , I took the step that I should have taken months, yes, years ago. I was stretched on a stiff, hard table, my arms were clamped down and in three- quarters of an hour I had my appendix and my gall bladder removed, which latter was a stone quarry and the former a cesspool.
title: The Letters of Franklin K. Lane, Personal and Political
author: Lane, Franklin K., 1864-1921; Lane, Anne Wintermute [Editor]; Wall, Louise Herrick, 1866- [Editor]

quoteLast: the wind moderated so much that we ventured to launch our remaining boat, now become the second, and in a few minutes both were riding alongside one another in the little cove. We then commenced pulling along the shore of the island, making about a south by east course.
title: Journals of Two Expeditions of Discovery in North-West and Western Australia, Volume 1
author: Grey, George, 1812-1898

quoteLast: , the servants of don Antonio de Carrera put the horses to the berlin, and a few minutes after the old gentleman came forth.

quoteLast: , the Queen, her husband, her family, and her Russian and German guests, bore down in the Royal yacht on Admiral Cochrane’s flagship, the _Duke of Wellington_. Having remained on board her for some little time, they returned to the yacht, and then, led by the Queen in the _Victoria and Albert_, this invincible Armada put out to sea in two divisions.
title: The Life and Times of Queen Victoria; vol. 2 of 4
author: Wilson, Robert, 1846-1893

quoteTime: About ten o’clock in the morning
quoteLast: , the Emperor went to ride for the first time. While he was mounting his horse, he was informed that the Resident of the East India Company in China had come to Longwood, and solicited the honour of being presented to him.
title: Memoirs of the life, exile, and conversations of the Emperor Napoleon. (Vol. II)

quoteLast: , where we were held in reserve until about 2 o’clock P. M., when we were ordered up. We crossed the creek, and made our way along a narrow, woody gorge up to the front.
title: The Military History of the 123d Regiment Ohio Volunteer Infantry
author: Keyes, C. M. (Charles M.) [Editor]

quoteLast: , I went out to procure some medicine for Christina. I was gone but a few minutes, and on my return, as I mounted the stairs, I was surprised to hear a strange voice in the sick-room. I entered and was introduced by Mrs. Jansen to 'Mrs. Brederhagan,' the rich widow, the mother of the little wretch who had assaulted Christina.
title: Cæsar's Column: A Story of the Twentieth Century
author: Donnelly, Ignatius, 1831-1901

quoteFirst: The 4th Brigade was ordered to attack a point marked P 14 and Cour l'Avoué at 9.30 A.M., but owing to the mist and bad weather the attack was indefinitely postponed, and the 2nd Battalion had to remain all day in its hastily made trench, which really offered very little resistance to artillery fire. The weather cleared
quoteLast: and the enemy began a terrific bombardment, which made things very unpleasant, although it did very little actual damage. It was not till 3.45 P.M. that the 2nd Battalion received orders to attack at 4.30 P.M., which gave no time for adequate preparation.
title: The Grenadier Guards in the Great War of 1914-1918, Vol. 1 of 3
author: Ponsonby, Frederick, 1867-1935; Cavan, Frederick Rudolph Lambart, Earl of, 1865-1946 [Author of introduction, etc.]; Walker, Emery, 1851-1933 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Who, hour after hour, finds himself ever worse bested;--those Granby people proving 'indescribable' once more [their Wutgenau also with his Hanoverians NOT being absent, as they rather were last night];--and
quoteLast: gives up the bad job; and sets about retiring.
title: History of Friedrich II of Prussia — Volume 20

quoteLast: , having got a fair breeze at E.S.E., we stood to the S.S.W., in hopes of getting round the foreland; but, as we drew near, we perceived more low isles, beyond the one already mentioned, which at last appeared to be connected by breakers, extending towards the foreland, and seeming to join the shore.
title: A Voyage Towards the South Pole and Round the World Volume 2
author: Cook, James, 1728-1779; Furneaux, Tobias, 1735-1781 [Contributor]

quoteFirst: A Lieutenant, 25, was wounded at Arras
quoteLast: October 20, 1914, just as he was leaning on another officer’s shoulder looking at a card in a chateau room. A shell burst in the court yard. A fragment came in the window, struck him in the back and pushed him forward, whereupon he felt pain in the back and a severe dyspnea, due to the gas from the shell.
title: Shell-shock and other neuropsychiatric problems
author: Southard, Elmer Ernest, 1876-1920

quoteFirst: The old Hall at Fulford, a strongly built, black and white, half-timbered erection of some centuries back, had been pulled down a few years before, and Sir James built the present house close to the old site. It was here that he was brought back in a dying state on June 13th, 1895,
quoteLast: , after riding out of the grounds only ten minutes before, full of life and energy. No one witnessed what occurred; he was a splendid horseman, but there was evidence that the horse, always inclined to be restive, had taken fright on passing a cottager's gate and tried to turn back, and that, as its master's whip was still firmly grasped in his hand, there had been a struggle.
title: My Experiences in Manipur and the Naga Hills
author: Johnstone, James, Sir, 1841-1895

quoteLast: and proceeded to the general store. Denton was sitting on the front porch, his usual place when the duties of the store did not demand his attention.
